title.narrative: 001 PREVENTION AND TREATMENT OF SAM

description.narrative: By 2025, prevention of wasting and treatment of children with acute malnutrition services are strengthened to deliver equitable quality and accessible services including during emergencies, which contributes to Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition (Covid), Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2025, chronic malnutrition (stunting) and wasting in children is reduced including in humanitarian situations

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2025, prevention of wasting and treatment of children with acute malnutrition services are strengthened to deliver equitablequality and accessible services including during emergencies

description.narrative: Between January and October 2021, 5 million under children were screened for acute malnutrition and UNICEF and partners successfully admitted 424,492 children suffering from SAM, representing 72% of the 2021 HRP. Compared to the same period last year, there is a 17.9% increase nationally and six regions are encountering significant increases: Gambella (3.0%), Oromia (16.6%), Somali (15.5%), Sidama (32.1%), SNNPR (32.1%), and Tigray (190.6%). This rise represents 64,430 additional children being admitted and 86% being in Oromia, Somali and SNNPR. This level of admissions was mainly due to conflict and insecurity, economic impacts of COVID-19 and others. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:07/01/2022
